item.title: Optical control of fast and processive engineered myosins in vitro and in living cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 18 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00740-7

High-performance engineered myosins robustly change speed or direction in response to an optical signal. In living cells, these motors localize to the tips of protrusions when illuminated and deliver molecular cargos.
item.dc:title: Optical control of fast and processive engineered myosins in vitro and in living cells

item.title: A community resource for paired genomic and metabolomic data mining
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 15 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-020-00724-z

Genomics and metabolomics are widely used to explore specialized metabolite diversity. The Paired Omics Data Platform is a community initiative to systematically document links between metabolome and (meta)genome data, aiding identification of natural product biosynthetic origins and metabolite structures.
item.dc:title: A community resource for paired genomic and metabolomic data mining

item.title: Peroxiredoxins couple metabolism and cell division in an ultradian cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 11 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-020-00728-9

Hydrogen peroxide and peroxiredoxin oxidation levels oscillate during the yeast metabolic cycle, while the absence of peroxiredoxins or the use of thiol oxidants and reductants disrupts metabolic cycling and its coupling with cell division.
item.dc:title: Peroxiredoxins couple metabolism and cell division in an ultradian cycle
item.dc:creator: Prince Saforo Amponsah

item.title: Structure- and mechanism-guided design of single fluorescent protein-based biosensors
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 08 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-020-00718-x

Using extensive knowledge about the structures and mechanisms of genetically encoded fluorescent biosensors, this Perspective provides guidelines to aid and accelerate the development of an increasingly broad range of high-performance imaging tools.
item.dc:title: Structure- and mechanism-guided design of single fluorescent protein-based biosensors
item.dc:creator: Yusuke Nasu
Yi Shen
Luke Kramer
Robert E. Campbell
item.dc:source: Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 2021-02-08; | doi:10.1038/s41589-020-00718-x

item.title: Author Correction: A cytochrome c is the natural electron acceptor for nicotine oxidoreductase
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 04 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00756-z

Author Correction: A cytochrome c is the natural electron acceptor for nicotine oxidoreductase
item.dc:title: Author Correction: A cytochrome c is the natural electron acceptor for nicotine oxidoreductase

item.dc:source: Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 2021-02-04; | doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00756-z

item.title: Synthetic protein quality control to enhance full-length translation in bacteria
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 04 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00736-3

A synthetic protein quality control system (ProQC) uses RNA hybridization to enhance translation of full-length proteins in coupled transcription–translation systems to optimize production of biosynthetic enzymes for metabolic engineering efforts.
item.dc:title: Synthetic protein quality control to enhance full-length translation in bacteria
item.dc:creator: Jina Yang
Yong Hee Han
Jongwon Im
Sang Woo Seo
item.dc:source: Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 2021-02-04; | doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00736-3

item.title: Yeast- and antibody-based tools for studying tryptophan C-mannosylation
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 04 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-020-00727-w

An engineered Pichia pastoris strain enables the synthesis of tryptophan C-mannosylated proteins, and selected monoclonal antibodies provide tools for detecting these modified proteins and studying their functions.
item.dc:title: Yeast- and antibody-based tools for studying tryptophan C-mannosylation
item.dc:creator: Alan John

item.dc:source: Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 2021-02-04; | doi:10.1038/s41589-020-00727-w

item.title: Phospholipase iPLA<sub>2</sub>β averts ferroptosis by eliminating a redox lipid death signal
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 04 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-020-00734-x

Ca2+-independent phospholipase A2β cleaves an oxidized form of phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) involved in ferroptosis such that increases in PE sensitize cells to ferroptosis. A mutant allele of the enzyme links neurodegeneration and ferroptosis.
item.dc:title: Phospholipase iPLA<sub>2</sub>β averts ferroptosis by eliminating a redox lipid death signal
